--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> Had you thought about the best way to determine the layer? I guess 
> you could calculate the shortest number of 'hops' for each hidden 
> neuron to an input neuron? Trouble is you might end up with all of 
> the neurons in layer 1 !!
> 
> 
> Colin

This is basically how I did it in my network display routine.  (See
for example the network picture at
www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html) I typically don't find
them all in one layer at all...it usually works out pretty well.  The
one thing to make sure of is not to count a recurrent connection as a
hop-  otherwise you can go in circles- but that requires also knowing
which connections are recurrent, which may also be difficult depending
how you keep track of things.  The problem is that this method is very
computationally expensive, and also requires always knowing which
connections are recurrent.  Once you get thousands of nodes I find it
starts lagging out a lot before drawing anything.

I think there are better ways.  I think Mat Buckland did something
clever to keep track of which neuron was in which layer, but I need to
reread his chapter on NEAT to remind myself of his method.  Maybe he
will have a comment if he's reading this.

ken
